issue.title: Allow IP address of interface to be changed
Allow IP address of interface to be changed

content.raw:
Just to restate things to make sure I understand the desired behavior:

* the hands have a fixed (known) IP address, as current
* a collection of machines are able to reach the hand (i.e. they are on the same subnet, or some other correctly routed network)
* through some packet, presumably sent over command-line or at the start of the ROS driver, a controlling machine is able to tell the hand its IP address (after which presumably the hand will do ARP)

Is that the behavior you'd like to see?

content.raw:
Yes.  
I was expecting the computer to make a socket connection to the hand, not vice versa.  Not sure why the hand needed hard coded computer IP, but it makes testing more difficult as we have multiple computers talking to the robot.

issue.title: Allow IP address of interface to be changed

content.raw:
The original intent of the implementation was just to keep things as simple as possible, since it was my understanding that the hands would only be operated on the robot. But it appears now that quite a few people are using them off the robot.

One thing I've done in the past on own machines is to use virtual IP addresses, which is pretty easy to do on Linux (just a few lines added to /etc/network/interfaces )

issue.title: Allow IP address of interface to be changed

content.raw:
at this point, I think I will call this a "wontfix" since we are past the 2013 DRC and this would require a firmware update to the hands, since unfortunately the microcontroller in the hand frame has the IP/port of the controlling computer hard-coded. If adding a virtual interface is impossible for your use cases, let me know and I can provide firmware tweaks and new flash images. 

However... burning these firmware images will require using the bootloader on the hand frame, and when the bootloader comes up, it always uses hard-coded IP/port values for the controlling computer, which would require that the hands are connected to a machine with a physical or virtual interface at the same ip/port as ATLAS.
